question_text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office because of decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and episodic abdominal pain for the past two months. The pain is sharp, colicky, and lasts about an hour after meals. Her stools are light in appearance and difficult to flush. Physical examination shows tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office because of decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and episodic abdominal pain for the past two months. The pain is sharp, colicky, and lasts about an hour after meals. Her stools are light in appearance and difficult to flush. Physical examination shows tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
hint: This patient's decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and postprandial, colicky right upper quadrant pain suggest cholelithiasis. The floating, light-colored stool likely results from fat malabsorption due to bile acid deficiency. Therefore, this patient is prone to developing fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies.
learning_objective: Recognize cholelithiasis, and recall complications of fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies.

answers.explanation_why: Deficiency of various water-soluble vitamins may cause glossitis. It would not be caused by malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (though a range of deficiencies can co-occur in some malabsorption conditions). The cholelithiasis and bile acid deficiency seen in this patient would not cause glossitis.

Megaloblastic anemia can be caused by vitamin B1 (thiamine), vitamin B9 (folic acid), or vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiencies, all of which are water-soluble vitamins. Fat malabsorption itself should not affect water-soluble vitamins, though some conditions include deficiency in both (e.g., concomitant B, D, and iron deficiency in celiac disease). Folic acid deficiency, for instance, can occur with a decreased intestinal surface area to absorb nutrients, increased physical demand (pregnancy), or decreased dietary intake. Pernicious anemia (vitamin B12 deficiency) can be due to intestinal malabsorption or lack of intrinsic factor. Thiamine deficiency is commonly observed in individuals with alcohol use disorder or diets reliant on polished rice and milled white cereals. Check for other malabsorption syndromes as a differential diagnosis.

Low bone mineral density is observed in patients with vitamin D deficiency, which can occur secondary to fat malabsorption, decreased intake, reduced sun exposure, decreased endogenous synthesis, or end-organ resistance to vitamin D. This patient is prone to developing other fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies (vitamin A, vitamin E, vitamin K), as well.

Impaired wound healing is observed in vitamin C deficiency and zinc deficiency, which result from inadequate dietary intake rather than fat malabsorption. Wound healing is also delayed in megaloblastic anemia and microcytic anemia. These can occur together with vitamin D deficiency in intestinal malabsorptive conditions. However, in a patient with fat malabsorption resulting from bile acid deficiency, delayed wound healing is not expected.

Hepatic steatosis can be alcohol or non-alcohol related. It may be observed in patients with surplus nutritional intake, protein malnutrition, toxin-induced liver damage, or other underlying diseases. A dysbalance in fatty acid metabolism or peripheral fat absorption traps triglycerides and other fatty acids in the liver. Decreased apolipoprotein and very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) synthesis can play a role. It is not expected in patients with fat malabsorption due to bile acid deficiency.

question_text: A 55-year-old man with a history of repeated hospitalization for chronic pancreatitis comes to the physician because of difficulty walking and standing steadily. Neurological examination shows an unsteady, broad-based gait, distal muscle weakness, decreased deep tendon reflexes, and an abnormal Romberg test. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.9 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 89/μm^3, and serum lactate dehydrogenase is 215 U/L. His serum haptoglobin is slightly decreased. A deficiency of which of the following substances is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man with a history of repeated hospitalization for chronic pancreatitis comes to the physician because of difficulty walking and standing steadily. Neurological examination shows an unsteady, broad-based gait, distal muscle weakness, decreased deep tendon reflexes, and an abnormal Romberg test. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.9 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 89/μm3, and serum lactate dehydrogenase is 215 U/L. His serum haptoglobin is slightly decreased. A deficiency of which of the following substances is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
hint: In infants, excess of this vitamin has been associated with necrotizing enterocolitis.
learning_objective: Recognize vitamin E deficiency, and recall its neurological manifestations.

answers.explanation_why: Deficiency of tocopherol (vitamin E deficiency) classically manifests with hemolytic anemia and symptoms of posterior column and spinocerebellar tract dysfunction (ataxia, loss of proprioception, and diminished reflexes). It is an uncommon condition in developed countries, but specific populations, such as patients with fat malabsorption disorders (e.g., chronic pancreatitis, abetalipoproteinemia, cystic fibrosis) are at significant risk. Vitamin E deficiency is harmful to neurons and red blood cells specifically as they are particularly sensitive to the oxidative damage that results from the loss of vitamin E antioxidative effects.

Riboflavin (vitamin B_2) deficiency can occur due to malnutrition (e.g., from a restricted diet), and it may present with normocytic normochromic anemia, as seen in this patient. However, it is not associated with neurological dysfunction but presents with instead with dry, scaling skin of the lips and mouth (cheilosis). Affected individuals may also have vision loss due to corneal vascularization.

Pyridoxine deficiency (vitamin B_6 deficiency) can occur with prolonged isoniazid administration and chronic alcohol use. It may present with neurological compromise, most often in the form of peripheral neuropathy, which could explain this patient's neurological findings. However, anemia associated with pyridoxine deficiency, if present, manifests as (microcytic) sideroblastic anemia, not (normocytic) hemolytic anemia.

Cobalamin (vitamin B_12) deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration, which may manifest with neurological signs and symptoms similar to the ones seen in this patient, including ataxia and muscle weakness. However, cobalamin deficiency typically also manifests with symmetrical paresthesias of the extremities and dementia. In addition, it causes megaloblastic anemia. Finally, common risk factors for this vitamin deficiency include restricted diets, lack of intrinsic factor, or terminal ileum disease (e.g., Crohn disease), none of which are present in this patient.

Niacin deficiency (vitamin B_3 deficiency) can be seen in severe malnutrition, carcinoid syndrome, or Hartnup disease. Moderate deficiency may cause glossitis whereas severe cases may lead to pellagra. However, neurological symptoms and hemolytic anemia would not be present.

images.title: Vitamin B₃ deficiency
images.description: Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

question_text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for sudden-onset slurring of speech and weakness of her right arm and leg. She has a mild intellectual disability. She is at the 10th percentile for weight and at the 85th percentile for height. Physical examination shows bilateral inferonasal subluxation of the lens and a high-arched palate. Her fingers are long and slender. Neurological examination shows an extensor plantar response on the right. This patient is most likely to respond to treatment with which of the following?
content_preview: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for sudden-onset slurring of speech and weakness of her right arm and leg. She has a mild intellectual disability. She is at the 10th percentile for weight and at the 85th percentile for height. Physical examination shows bilateral inferonasal subluxation of the lens and a high-arched palate. Her fingers are long and slender. Neurological examination shows an extensor plantar response on the right. This patient is most likely to respond to treatment with which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with signs of an acute stroke (hemiplegia, slurred speech, positive Babinski sign), Marfanoid habitus (tall stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly), inferonasal lens subluxation, and intellectual disability, indicating homocystinuria most likely caused by cystathionine synthase deficiency.
learning_objective: Recognize homocystinuria, and choose the appropriate vitamin supplementation.

answers.explanation_why: Supplementation of methionine is the treatment of choice for homocystinuria caused by defective methionine synthase. However, it is a rare cause of homocystinuria, and symptoms typically present earlier and more acutely. In all other forms of homocystinuria, methionine intake should be restricted in order to prevent further accumulation of homocysteine.

Together with tyrosine supplementation, dietary restriction of phenylalanine is the treatment of choice for patients with phenylketonuria (PKU). Although PKU does present with intellectual disabilities, which are seen in this patient, it is not associated with marfanoid habitus, lens luxation, or vascular events. Moreover, patients with PKU typically have a history of seizures and skin disorders such as eczema and may have a characteristic musty body odor.

Alkalinization of the urine to a pH > 7 through the administration of potassium citrate or potassium bicarbonate dissolves cystine stones formed in cystinuria. However, homocystinuria does not lead to the formation of cystine stones, and patients would not benefit from such a treatment.

Vitamin B6 is a cofactor of cystathionine synthase, which catalyzes the first step of conversion of homocysteine and serine into cystathionine. Homocystinuria caused by cystathionine synthase deficiency or decreased affinity of the enzyme for vitamin B6 can be treated with B6 supplementation. However, only about 50% of patients are pyridoxine-responsive. Because cystathionine synthase deficiency results in the accumulation of thrombogenic homocysteine, it predisposes to thromboembolic events (e.g., acute stroke). Lowering the plasma homocysteine concentration is therefore the single most important factor for reducing the risk of vascular events.
Homocystinuria is most commonly caused by defective conversion of homocysteine to cysteine. Subsequently, cysteine levels are usually decreased and supplementation is indicated, not restriction.

question_text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine physical examination. He feels well. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count and a standard electrolyte panel, are within normal limits. Urine dipstick is negative for glucose; a reducing substance test result of the urine is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate dietary recommendation for this patient?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine physical examination. He feels well. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count and a standard electrolyte panel, are within normal limits. Urine dipstick is negative for glucose; a reducing substance test result of the urine is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate dietary recommendation for this patient?
hint: The patient has a reducing sugar in his urine which is not glucose. As he is asymptomatic and has an otherwise completely normal exam the sugar is most likely fructose, leading to the diagnosis of essential fructosuria.
learning_objective: Recognize essential fructosuria from urine test results, and choose the appropriate dietary recommendation for the patient.

answers.explanation_why: Eliminating fructose and sucrose from the diet would be recommended in hereditary fructose intolerance, which is characterized by fructose-1-phosphate accumulation, phosphate depletion, and inhibition of glycolytic pathways. Although a reducing sugar (fructose) could be detected in the urine (as is the case in this patient), hereditary fructose intolerance would present in early childhood with severe hypoglycemia, vomiting, jaundice, bleeding, hepatomegaly, and failure to thrive.

Decreasing purine intake would be recommended in conditions associated with hyperuricemia (e.g., primary gout, renal failure, Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, tumor lysis syndrome, von Gierke disease). This patient, however, is an asymptomatic adult.

No treatment is required for patients with essential fructosuria, a benign disorder of fructose metabolism caused by the deficiency of fructokinase, which converts fructose to fructose-1-phosphate. Although fructokinase deficiency can lead to detectable fructose in the blood and urine, the condition has no clinical consequences, as hexokinase shunts excess fructose back into the glycolytic pathway by converting fructose directly to fructose-6-phosphate.

images.title: Mechanisms of fructose intolerance
images.description: (1) Essential fructosuria is an inherited benign metabolic disorder that is due to a deficiency of the fructokinase enzyme within the liver.(2) Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive defect in the fructose metabolism pathway due to an aldolase B enzyme deficiency.

answers.explanation_why: Eliminating galactose and lactose from the diet would be recommended in galactosemia, which is characterized by the accumulation of galactose and galactitol. Although galactosemia can present with a reducing sugar (galactose) in the urine, as seen in this patient, it presents as soon as an infant starts feeding with infantile cataracts, jaundice, vomiting, hepatosplenomegaly, and failure to thrive.

answers.content: Increase intake of ketogenic amino acids
answers.explanation_why: Increasing intake of ketogenic amino acids may delay the progression of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency, which is caused by a dysfunction of the citric acid cycle leading to lactate build-up. It manifests early in life with nonspecific symptoms like lethargy, poor feeding, tachypnea, neurodevelopmental delays, and lactic acidosis. This patient is, however, asymptomatic and does not have a history of consistent symptoms.

question_text: A 2710-g (6-lb) male newborn is delivered at 38 weeks of gestation to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. The pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated. Breastfeeding is initiated. Which of the following is indicated in this newborn to prevent a potentially life-threatening condition?
content_preview: A 2710-g (6-lb) male newborn is delivered at 38 weeks of gestation to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. The pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated. Breastfeeding is initiated. Which of the following is indicated in this newborn to prevent a potentially life-threatening condition?
hint: This vitamin is used in gamma-carboxylation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X.
learning_objective: Recognize the risk of hemorrhagic disease in newborns, and choose the appropriate supplement to prevent it.

answers.explanation_why: Vitamin B1 (thiamine), like all water-soluble vitamins, crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk. Infants born to thiamine-deficient mothers can develop infantile beriberi, which, if untreated, can be life-threatening. However, thiamine deficiency usually occurs in countries where the main diet is composed of polished white rice or as a result of chronic alcohol abuse.

Fluoride crosses the placental barrier and is present in breast milk following environmental exposure. Most newborns have already accumulated measurable levels at birth. In regions where the drinking water is not fluoridated, the current recommendation is to administer fluoride to children but not before the age of 6 months due to the risk of fluorosis. Using fluoride to support dental hygiene protects against dental caries, which is not a life-threatening condition.

Vitamin K levels are low in all newborns because very little crosses the placental barrier, and its concentration in breast milk is insignificant. In addition, newborns have sterile intestines, and the establishment of gut microflora that synthesizes vitamin K takes approximately 6 months. As vitamin K is necessary for the production of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, not supplementing it within a few hours after birth can enable a potentially fatal hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. Another risk factor for vitamin K deficiency bleeding of the newborn is prolonged use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Folic acid (vitamin B9), like all water-soluble vitamins, crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk, making postnatal supplementation unnecessary. Individuals planning pregnancy should be supplied with folic acid beginning ≥ 4 weeks before trying to conceive and continuing until 12 weeks' gestation to prevent neural tube defects. Infants born to folate-deficient mothers can develop megaloblastic anemia, but this carries no immediate postnatal complication or risk of mortality.

Iron stores in newborns are sufficient for the first 6 months of life, so immediate postnatal supplementation is not routinely required. Although breast milk contains only a small amount of iron, its bioavailability is high, which helps protect infants from iron deficiency during this period. After around 6 months of age, the introduction of iron-rich foods is recommended to prevent iron deficiency anemia.

Since vitamin D crosses the placenta, most newborns have adequate levels at birth. Furthermore, vitamin D deficiency would usually remain asymptomatic unless it led to rickets, which is not a life-threatening condition and not common in industrialized nations. However, as the amount of vitamin D in breastmilk is usually not sufficient to meet infants' daily requirements, vitamin D supplementation is recommended in exclusively and partially breastfed infants starting within the first few days of birth.

question_text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of generalized bone pain. She has a 25-year history of Crohn disease with multiple hospitalizations for acute exacerbations, including a bowel obstruction last year. Current medications include azathioprine and bisoprolol. She is 165 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 53 kg (117 lb); her BMI is 19.5 kg/m^2. Examination shows a soft abdomen and pale conjunctivae. Neurological examination shows decreased vibratory sensation over her lower extremities. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the distal groups and 3/5 in proximal groups of the lower limbs. The pelvic bones are tender to palpation. An x-ray of the pelvis shows thin cortices and multiple radiolucent bands that are perpendicular to the cortex and surrounded by a thin sclerotic margin. Which of the following laboratory findings are most likely present in this patient?

Calcium
Phosphate
Alkaline phosphatase
Parathyroid hormone

A

content_preview: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of generalized bone pain. She has a 25-year history of Crohn disease with multiple hospitalizations for acute exacerbations, including a bowel obstruction last year. Current medications include azathioprine and bisoprolol. She is 165 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 53 kg (117 lb); her BMI is 19.5 kg/m2. Examination shows a soft abdomen and pale conjunctivae. Neurological examination shows decreased vibratory sensation over her lower extremities. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the distal groups and 3/5 in proximal groups of the lower limbs. The pelvic bones are tender to palpation. An x-ray of the pelvis shows thin cortices and multiple radiolucent bands that are perpendicular to the cortex and surrounded by a thin sclerotic margin. Which of the following laboratory findings are most likely present in this patient? Calcium Phosphate Alkaline phosphatase Parathyroid hormone A Normal normal normal normal B Normal normal ↑ normal C ↓ ↓ ↑ ↑ D ↑ ↓ ↑ ↑ E ↓ ↑ ↑ ↑ F ↑ ↑ ↑ ↓ G ↓ ↑ normal ↓
hint: This patient's history of Crohn disease combined with her physical exam findings of pale conjunctiva and decreased vibratory sensation suggests malabsorption as the underlying cause for her bone pain. Bone pain combined with thin cortices and Looser zones (transverse radiolucent bands) on x-ray indicates osteomalacia.
learning_objective: Recognize vitamin D deficiency, and recall its laboratory findings.

answers.explanation_why: Normal calcium, phosphorus, PTH, and ALP levels in an elderly female patient with bone pain are characteristic of osteoporosis. Osteoporosis would result in cortical thinning and increased radiolucency due to decreased bone density. However, bone sclerosis would not be expected, and the bone would be diffusely radiolucent, in contrast to the osteolytic lesions seen in this patient, which have a distinctive transverse band-like appearance on x-ray. Moreover, osteoporosis would not explain the myopathic weakness seen here.

High serum ALP and normal calcium, phosphorus, and PTH levels in an elderly patient with bone pain are characteristic of Paget disease of the bone (PDB). However, while PDB lesions can have a mixed lytic (radiolucent) and sclerotic appearance, they typically appear as lytic lesions within a background of diffuse sclerosis. Furthermore, a thin cortex would not be seen in PDB.

images.title: Paget disease of pelvis
images.description: X-ray pelvisEnlargement of the right hemipelvis is accompanied by coarsened trabeculation and areas of sclerosis compatible with abnormal remodeling in Paget disease (green overlay).

answers.explanation_why:
Severe vitamin D deficiency can lead to hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia by decreasing the amount of calcium and phosphate absorption in the intestine. As long as calcium levels are low, increased PTH secretion occurs in an attempt to maintain normal serum calcium levels (secondary hyperparathyroidism). PTH releases calcium stored in bone into serum by increasing bone turnover, which the elevated ALP levels (a marker of bone turnover) indicate here. Increased PTH levels also worsen hypophosphatemia by decreasing renal phosphate reabsorption.

Chronic inflammation of the ileum in patients with Crohn disease can cause impaired reabsorption of bile acids, resulting in fat malabsorption; unabsorbed fats can trap fat-soluble vitamins (e.g., vitamin D) in the intestinal lumen, causing a deficiency.

Decreased phosphate and increased calcium, ALP, and PTH levels are characteristic of primary hyperparathyroidism, which typically occurs in elderly women and causes bone pain. A pelvic x-ray in a patient with primary hyperparathyroidism can show cortical thinning as well as focal osteolytic lesions. However, the osteolytic lesions in patients with primary hyperparathyroidism are usually round/polygonal circumscribed lesions rather than the distinctive transverse band-like lesions seen here.

Bone pain with decreased calcium and increased phosphate, ALP, and PTH levels can be seen in patients with secondary hyperparathyroidism due to ESRD (renal osteodystrophy), as well as in patients with pseudohypoparathyroidism (PHP). Also, patients with PHP or renal osteodystrophy can have muscle weakness (due to myopathy) and radiological features of osteomalacia such as Looser zones, as seen here. However, renal osteodystrophy would not occur until the very late stage of CKD (i.e., when renal replacement therapy is required). PHP, on the other hand, would typically manifest during childhood with features of Albright hereditary osteodystrophy (e.g., short stature, round face, obesity, short fourth metacarpals, soft tissue calcifications, dental hypoplasia).

Osteolytic metastases, which appear as radiolucent lesions, can result in increased calcium, phosphorus, and ALP levels, together with decreased PTH levels. Bone metastases should be considered in any elderly patient with bone pain even if the primary tumor is not clinically evident. Hypercalcemia could also explain muscle weakness in this patient. However, the transverse band-like appearance of the radiolucent lesions in this woman suggests a different diagnosis, as osteolytic metastases usually appear as ill-defined, round lesions on x-ray.

Decreased calcium and PTH levels with normal serum ALP levels and increased phosphate are consistent with primary hypoparathyroidism, which can result in decreased muscle strength. However, features of bone disease are usually absent in patients with primary hypoparathyroidism. Moreover, in adults, primary hypoparathyroidism is typically caused by iatrogenic damage to the parathyroid glands during neck surgery (e.g., thyroidectomy) or neck irradiation.
answers.explanation_but: Rarely (< 1% of cases), primary hypoparathyroidism occurs as a result of autoimmune disease or infiltrative diseases of the parathyroid glands (e.g., sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis, Wilson disease, metastases).

question_text: A 3-week old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of lethargy, recurrent vomiting, and poor weight gain since birth. Physical examination shows decreased skin turgor and a bulging frontal fontanelle. Serum studies show an ammonia concentration of 170 μmol/L (N < 30) and low serum citrulline levels. The oral intake of which of the following nutrients should be restricted in this patient?
content_preview: A 3-week old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of lethargy, recurrent vomiting, and poor weight gain since birth. Physical examination shows decreased skin turgor and a bulging frontal fontanelle. Serum studies show an ammonia concentration of 170 μmol/L (N < 30) and low serum citrulline levels. The oral intake of which of the following nutrients should be restricted in this patient?
hint: Findings of increased serum orotic acid levels would help differentiate between ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency and carbamoyl phosphate synthase 1 deficiency as a cause of this patient's urea cycle disorder.
learning_objective: Recall the management of urea cycle disorders, and recall the metabolic consequences of these disorders.

answers.explanation_why: Fructose intake would have to be restricted in patients with aldolase B deficiency (hereditary fructose intolerance), which can cause hepatotoxicity with subsequent hyperammonemia and resulting symptoms such as anterior fontanelle bulging (due to increased ICP in hepatic encephalopathy), vomiting with features of dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor), lethargy, and failure to thrive, as seen in this infant. However, patients with hyperammonemia due to hepatotoxicity would have icterus. Furthermore, aldolase B deficiency would not cause low citrulline levels, but rather hypoglycemia.

images.title: Mechanisms of fructose intolerance
images.description: (1) Essential fructosuria is an inherited benign metabolic disorder that is due to a deficiency of the fructokinase enzyme within the liver.(2) Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive defect in the fructose metabolism pathway due to an aldolase B enzyme deficiency.

answers.explanation_why: The urea cycle is responsible for the conversion of toxic nitrogenous waste (NH_3) generated from amino acid catabolism to urea, which is then excreted by the kidneys. In individuals with hyperammonemia due to urea cycle disorders or hepatotoxicity, dietary protein restriction can limit the amount of NH_3 generated from amino acids.

images.title: Urea cycle
images.description: The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic vitamin A toxicity may cause pseudotumor cerebri and hepatotoxicity with subsequent hyperammonemia. Infants with this condition can, therefore, develop anterior fontanelle bulging, vomiting with features of dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor), and lethargy, which are also seen here. However, patients with hyperammonemia due to hepatotoxicity would have icterus, and vitamin A toxicity would not cause low citrulline levels. Moreover, other features of chronic vitamin A toxicity, such as alopecia and dry skin, would be expected on examination.

Fatty acid intake would require restriction in patients with medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency, which can cause hepatotoxicity with subsequent hyperammonemia and resulting symptoms such as anterior fontanelle bulging (due to increased ICP in hepatic encephalopathy), vomiting with features of dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor), lethargy, and failure to thrive, as seen in this infant. However, patients with hyperammonemia due to hepatotoxicity would have icterus. Furthermore, MCAD deficiency would not cause low citrulline levels, but rather hypoglycemia and increased fatty acylcarnitine levels.

Gluten would require restriction in patients with celiac disease, which can cause lethargy and failure to thrive due to malabsorption. However, the symptoms of pediatric celiac disease typically only begin at 9–24 months. Furthermore, features such as nausea, vomiting, a bulging anterior fontanelle, decreased skin turgor, hyperammonemia, and low citrulline levels would not be expected.

Lactose intake would have to be restricted in patients with classic galactosemia, which can cause hepatotoxicity with subsequent hyperammonemia and resulting symptoms such as anterior fontanelle bulging (due to increased ICP in hepatic encephalopathy), vomiting with features of dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor), lethargy, and failure to thrive, as seen in this infant. However, patients with hyperammonemia due to hepatotoxicity would have icterus. Furthermore, classic galactosemia would not cause low citrulline levels and would likely manifest with infantile cataracts.

question_text:
Patient information
Age: 82 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: White, self-identified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I have been getting these large bruises on my arms and legs.”
History of Present Illness:

his wife noticed 6 weeks ago that he had bruising on the bilateral lower extremities
additional ecchymoses developed on the bilateral upper extremities 2 weeks ago
feels increasingly fatigued
has pain in the elbows, hips, and knees

was unable to complete his final cycle of chemotherapy for non-small cell lung carcinoma because of the pain
has not had trauma or prior episodes of significant bleeding

Past Medical History: 

hypertension
benign prostatic hyperplasia
osteoarthritis
non-small cell lung carcinoma treated with resection; currently undergoing adjuvant chemotherapy

Medications:

hint: This patient's history of decreased appetite and low BMI (17 kg/m^2) suggest malnutrition, which is complicated by a vitamin deficiency as indicated by impaired wound healing and an impaired immune response.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical manifestations of vitamin C deficiency.

answers.explanation_why: Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) results in impaired collagen synthesis and easily-damaged connective tissue, which manifests with swollen gums and mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs (corkscrew hairs), perifollicular hemorrhages, anemia (fatigue, pallor), and easy bruising (e.g., multiple ecchymoses). His joint pain may be caused by hemarthroses from vitamin C deficiency or may be due to his underlying osteoarthritis. Populations at increased risk for developing nutritional deficiencies include individuals with substance use disorders, the elderly, and patients who are chronically ill, such as this man with non-small cell lung carcinoma who may have poor intake due to loss of appetite and chemotherapy-induced nausea. The treatment for scurvy is vitamin C supplementation.

Vitamin A deficiency is associated with several ocular and dermatologic manifestations, including night blindness, xerophthalmia, keratomalacia, Bitot spots, and xerosis. In addition, vitamin A deficiency does not cause mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs, perifollicular hemorrhages, or ecchymoses.

Vitamin D deficiency can cause osteomalacia and symptoms of hypocalcemia (e.g., paresthesias, muscle spasms). It does not cause anemia (fatigue, pallor), mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs, perifollicular hemorrhages, or ecchymoses.

Vitamin B_12 deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy (decreased sensation in the lower extremities) as well as fatigue and pallor (due to macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia). However, this patient's peripheral neuropathy is likely caused by cisplatin-based chemotherapy. Other symptoms of vitamin B_12 deficiency include ataxia and spasticity (due to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord) and manifestations of neuropsychiatric diseases such as dementia and depression. Moreover, vitamin B_12 deficiency does not cause mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs, perifollicular hemorrhages, or ecchymoses.

Vitamin B_6 deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy (decreased sensation in the lower extremities) as well as fatigue and pallor (due to sideroblastic anemia). However, this patient's peripheral neuropathy is likely caused by cisplatin-based chemotherapy. Other symptoms of vitamin B_6 deficiency include cheilitis, glossitis, and stomatitis. Moreover, vitamin B_6 deficiency does not cause mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs, perifollicular hemorrhages, or ecchymoses.

Vitamin K is a cofactor for factors II (prothrombin), VII, IX, and X of the coagulation cascade; vitamin K deficiency causes coagulopathy that could manifest with ecchymoses, mucosal bleeding, and pallor. However, vitamin K deficiency does not cause coiled hairs. In addition, perifollicular hemorrhages are highly specific for another nutritional deficiency.

question_text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive weakness in his upper extremities over the past 7 months. He initially noticed difficulty writing but now has difficulty performing his activities of daily living. He currently lives with his son. He has no personal or family history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is mild atrophy and twitching of the tongue. Muscle strength is decreased in the upper extremities and normal in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the upper extremities, 4+ in the right lower extremity, and 2+ in the left lower extremity. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is intact in all extremities. On mental status examination, he is cooperative with a mildly anxious mood and a neutral affect. His speech is slightly slurred and hypernasal. Needle electromyography shows spontaneous fasciculation potentials in multiple muscles, fibrillations, and positive sharp wave potentials. Spirometry shows an FVC of 85% of predicted. A diagnosis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is made and treatment with riluzole is initiated. After discussion with the patient and his son, a decision to transfer the patient to hospice care is made. Before transferring the patient to hospice care, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

He initially noticed difficulty writing but now has difficulty performing his activities of daily living. He currently lives with his son. He has no personal or family history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is mild atrophy and twitching of the tongue. Muscle strength is decreased in the upper extremities and normal in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the upper extremities, 4+ in the right lower extremity, and 2+ in the left lower extremity. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is intact in all extremities. On mental status examination, he is cooperative with a mildly anxious mood and a neutral affect. His speech is slightly slurred and hypernasal. Needle electromyography shows spontaneous fasciculation potentials in multiple muscles, fibrillations, and positive sharp wave potentials. Spirometry shows an FVC of 85% of predicted. A diagnosis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is made and treatment with riluzole is initiated. After discussion with the patient and his son, a decision to transfer the patient to hospice care is made. Before transferring the patient to hospice care, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with features of bulbar palsy (e.g., tongue atrophy and fasciculations, dysarthria, hypernasal speech) as a manifestation of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Bulbar palsy can cause a symptom that increases the morbidity of patients with ALS and should therefore be assessed.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in management before transferring a patient with ALS to hospice care.

answers.explanation_why: Noninvasive ventilation is indicated in patients with ALS with respiratory failure (e.g., orthopnea, vital capacity < 50%). This patient does not have symptoms of respiratory insufficiency (e.g., tachypnea, hypoxemia).

Genetic testing for specific ALS-causing mutations is useful in identifying familial ALS, which accounts for up to 10% of all ALS cases. Genetic testing is indicated in patients with a family history of ALS or juvenile-onset ALS, neither of which have been reported here.

Amitriptyline can be used to treat patients with ALS who present with features of depression or pseudobulbar affect. This patient does not have symptoms of depression and mental status examination shows a normal affect.

ALS is characterized by concomitant upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron dysfunction and can manifest with pseudobulbar palsy and bulbar palsy, both of which result in dysphagia. Dysphagia increases the risk for aspiration and/or insufficient fluid and food intake, leading to complications in patients with ALS (e.g., aspiration pneumonia, weight loss). A bedside swallowing test should therefore be performed in all patients with ALS to screen for dysphagia. If the test is positive, a formal swallowing study (e.g., videofluoroscopic swallowing examination) is required to confirm the diagnosis. Patients with ALS who have swallowing difficulties may need specialized nutritional support (e.g., pureed food, thickened liquids, nasogastric tube, percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy). Bedside swallowing test is also performed for other neurological conditions that manifest with dysphagia, such as Parkinson disease, acute stroke, and Guillain-Barré syndrome.

In addition to the bedside swallowing test, this patient should be asked about their wishes regarding resuscitation. ALS can result in cognitive impairment in the later stages, and the patient's resuscitation wishes (e.g., do not resuscitate order) should be determined while their mental faculties are intact.
Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy is indicated in patients with ALS who have symptomatic dysphagia or significant weight loss, none of which are seen here.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 21 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “The pain in my leg is unbearable.”
History of Present Illness:

5-week history of pain in right lower extremity
pain worsens with activity and is relieved with rest and ibuprofen
no history of trauma
patient is a professional dancer and practices 6–8 hours most days of the week; she is very worried that she will have to stop dancing

Past Medical History:

one urinary tract infection; treated successfully 2 months ago
no serious illness

Medications:
ibuprofen
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
noncontributory
Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

35.8°C
(96.4°F)

51/min
14/min
100/62 mm Hg
-

178 cm
(5 ft 10 in)
60 kg
(132 lb)
19 kg/m^2

Appearance: mildly uncomfortable
Skin: xerosis; no rashes
Pulmonary: clear lung fields
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Abdominal: soft and nontender; liver and spleen cannot be palpated
Extremities: tenderness and mild swelling over the medial aspect of the right proximal tibia; hopping on the right leg exacerbates pain; dorsalis pedis pulses intact
Neurologic: muscle strength 5/5 throughout; sensation intact

Diagnostic Studies

x-ray of the right knee: shown

It is most appropriate to obtain specific additional history regarding which of the following?

hint: This patient's x-ray of the right knee shows a stress fracture in the medial proximal tibial metaphysis.
learning_objective: Recognize a stress fracture, and recall its risk factors.

answers.explanation_why: Morning stiffness can occur in osteoarthritis, which manifests with pain that worsens during or after exercise and is relieved with rest. However, x-rays in osteoarthritis typically show irregular joint space narrowing, osteophytes, and/or subchondral sclerosis, but not stress fractures. Additionally, osteoarthritis is most common in individuals aged > 50 years.

Night sweats and long-lasting bone pain can occur in infectious bone diseases (e.g., chronic osteomyelitis, bone tuberculosis) and in certain bone tumors (e.g., osteosarcoma). However, x-rays in chronic osteomyelitis show bone destruction, sequestrum formation, and/or periosteal reactions. In osteosarcoma, x-rays show lytic bone lesions adjacent to sclerotic lesions (moth-eaten appearance) and/or Codman triangles. Stress fractures are not typically seen in these diseases.

This patient may have received a fluoroquinolone for her recent urinary tract infection. One side effect of fluoroquinolones is tendinopathy, which causes pain that worsens with physical activity. However, fluoroquinolone tendinopathy most commonly affects the Achilles tendon and does not cause stress fractures of the tibia.

Repetitive microtrauma can cause bone remodeling, leading to stress fractures. Risk factors for stress fractures include female sex, prolonged periods of high-intensity activity (e.g., dancing) without adequate rest, and poor nutrition and/or low calorie intake. Many athletes have borderline low BMI and blood pressure as well as physiological sinus bradycardia. However, these findings in combination with xerosis and low body temperature raise suspicion for caloric restriction, which requires evaluation of dietary history.

Other risk factors for stress fractures include calcium and vitamin D deficiencies, improper technique during physical activity, and ill-fitting footwear.

Urinary symptoms such as foamy urine (due to proteinuria) can occur in multiple myeloma (MM), features of which include spontaneous fractures and bone pain. However, MM most commonly manifests with back pain, not limb pain, and with signs of anemia and hypercalcemia (e.g., constipation, muscle weakness). Additionally, x-rays in MM show lytic lesions, which appear as punched-out holes.

Cigarette smoking is a risk factor for osteoporosis, which can lead to stress fractures. However, the onset of osteoporosis typically occurs at 50–70 years of age. This patient's young age and other examination findings (e.g., bradycardia, low BMI) suggest another cause for reduced bone density.

images.title: Tibial stress fracture
images.description: X-ray right knee (left: AP view; right: lateral view) of a patient with a history of atraumatic leg pain following intense exerciseAn irregular linear lucency (green overlay) accompanied by sclerosis (arrowheads) is seen in the medial proximal tibial metaphysis. The appearance is compatible with a stress fracture.The sensitivity of x-ray for the detection of early-stage stress fractures is low, although increases as the fracture heals. Examples of positive findings include a visible fracture line, sclerosis or cortical thickening, and periosteal reaction. MRI is the most sensitive modality for the detection of a stress fracture.

question_text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because they are concerned about her desire to adopt a strict vegan diet. She has been a vegetarian ever since she watched a documentary about industrial livestock farming. Last month, she joined a group of friends who toured a dairy farm in their neighboring village in Montana, which convinced her to become a vegan and consume only unprocessed foods. She eats a well-balanced diet rich in vegetables, fruits, seeds, and nuts. The parents are concerned that she will not get enough nutrition. The patient just finished her soccer season and plans on joining the ski team for the winter season next month. She has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. She is annoyed about the concerns of her parents and believes a vegan diet will not only help save animal lives but also protect the planet. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m^2. The physician should counsel the patient that without supplements, she is at increased risk of developing which of the following nutritional deficiency?
content_preview: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because they are concerned about her desire to adopt a strict vegan diet. She has been a vegetarian ever since she watched a documentary about industrial livestock farming. Last month, she joined a group of friends who toured a dairy farm in their neighboring village in Montana, which convinced her to become a vegan and consume only unprocessed foods. She eats a well-balanced diet rich in vegetables, fruits, seeds, and nuts. The parents are concerned that she will not get enough nutrition. The patient just finished her soccer season and plans on joining the ski team for the winter season next month. She has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. She is annoyed about the concerns of her parents and believes a vegan diet will not only help save animal lives but also protect the planet. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. The physician should counsel the patient that without supplements, she is at increased risk of developing which of the following nutritional deficiency?
hint: A vegan diet excludes all meat and animal products such as milk and milk products.
learning_objective: Recall the common nutritional deficiencies associated with a vegan diet.

answers.explanation_why: Although folate can be found in meat (especially liver), the main sources of folate are leafy green vegetables. It is highly unlikely that this girl will develop folate deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet. Important causes of folate deficiency include severe malnutrition (e.g., “tea and toast” diet, chronic alcohol use), malabsorption (e.g., intestinal resection, celiac disease), increased folate demand (e.g., pregnancy, hemolytic anemia), and medication use (e.g., methotrexate, phenytoin).

Fiber is found in a large number of fruits (e.g., prunes, apples), vegetables (e.g., beans, lentils), and grains (e.g., oatmeal, wheat). It is highly unlikely this girl will develop fiber deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet.

Although phenylalanine, an essential amino acid, is mainly found in animal products, such as meat, eggs, and dairy, it can also be found in plant-based products such as nuts, soybean, squash, and wheat. It is unlikely this girl will develop deficiency of any amino acids after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet.

Although vitamin B_6 can be found in meat (especially poultry and liver), the main sources of vitamin B_6 are nuts, whole grains, and vegetables. It is highly unlikely this girl will develop vitamin B_6 deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet. Important causes of vitamin B_6 deficiency include severe malnutrition, chronic alcohol use, and medication use (e.g., isoniazid, hydralazine).

People who follow a vegan diet have a higher risk of developing vitamin D deficiency compared to the general population. This is due to the fact that a vegan diet does not include dairy, which is a major dietary source of vitamin D. Therefore, individuals who transition to a vegan diet should be advised to consume sufficient amounts of vitamin D-fortified foods (e.g., plant-based milk alternatives, cereal, juices) to achieve the recommended daily dose of vitamin D. They should also be counseled on the importance of exposure to sunlight, another major source of vitamin D, to boost the endogenous production of vitamin D, which is often deficient in individuals who live in northern latitudes (like this patient from Montana), especially during the Winter season.

Apart from vitamin D, a vegan diet is often deficient in calcium, vitamin B_12, and iron. Patients should be counseled on supplementation to avoid nutritional deficiencies.

question_text: A 73-year-old patient is evaluated in the hospital after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that lasted 5 minutes. Four days ago, he was admitted for dysphagia secondary to esophageal cancer. Uncomplicated percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) was performed the day after admission and the patient was started on specialized nutritional support via the PEG tube. He appears emaciated, fatigued, and mildly diaphoretic. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 17 kg/m^2. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting, pretibial edema bilaterally. Serum creatinine concentration is 0.6 mg/dL and creatine kinase activity is 20 U/L. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
content_preview: A 73-year-old patient is evaluated in the hospital after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that lasted 5 minutes. Four days ago, he was admitted for dysphagia secondary to esophageal cancer. Uncomplicated percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) was performed the day after admission and the patient was started on specialized nutritional support via the PEG tube. He appears emaciated, fatigued, and mildly diaphoretic. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 17 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting, pretibial edema bilaterally. Serum creatinine concentration is 0.6 mg/dL and creatine kinase activity is 20 U/L. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
hint: Rapid reinitiation of normal nutrition in a chronically malnourished patient can lead to refeeding syndrome (RS), which causes electrolyte shifts between the extracellular and intracellular space.
learning_objective: Recognize refeeding syndrome, and recall its associated electrolyte abnormality.

answers.explanation_why: In prolonged catabolic states (e.g., due to chronic malnutrition), energy stores, as well as vitamins (notably thiamine) and intracellular electrolytes are depleted. Renutrition and ensuing rising glucose concentrations cause insulin release, which leads to an intracellular shift of glucose, phosphorus (needed for phosphorylation of glucose in glycolysis), magnesium, and potassium. The resulting drops in serum electrolyte concentrations can cause severe complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias and seizures. To prevent RS, energy intake should be increased gradually and serum electrolytes must be monitored closely and repleted as necessary.

Hypermagnesemia can occur in the later stages of RS if rhabdomyolysis and ensuing renal failure develop. However, this patient's normal serum creatinine concentration, as well as mildly decreased creatinine kinase (due to malnutrition), exclude these conditions. Increased insulin release in patients with RS causes an intracellular shift of electrolytes. Therefore, a decreased, rather than increased serum magnesium concentration is expected.

Renutrition and ensuing rising glucose concentrations cause insulin release. In refeeding syndrome, increased rather than decreased serum insulin concentration is responsible for intracellular electrolyte shifts.

Hyperkalemia may be seen in patients with RS due to significant myocyte damage caused by seizures or rhabdomyolysis. However, if significant myocyte damage were present, serum creatine kinase would be elevated. Increased insulin release in patients with RS activates the Na+/K+-ATPase, resulting in an intracellular shift of potassium and a decreased, rather than increased serum potassium concentration.

Increased serum ketoacid concentration is seen in catabolic states such as diabetic ketoacidosis (due to insulin deficiency) or starvation ketoacidosis, both of which are associated with fatty acid breakdown. During renutrition, glucose-dependent metabolic pathways are increasingly activated. Since thiamine is a cofactor for these pathways, renutrition can lead to thiamine deficiency, which can result in lactic acidosis (because thiamine is also necessary for the conversion of lactate to pyruvate) but not ketoacidosis.

question_text: A 48-year-old man comes to the clinic because of bleeding gums, fatigue, and joint pain for the past three weeks. He is currently unemployed and has been living in a homeless shelter for the past two months. His diet consists mainly of bread and instant noodles; he rarely consumes fruits or vegetables. He has a history of alcohol use disorder and smokes one pack of cigarettes daily. The patient appears thin and pale. BMI is 17.3 kg/m^2. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Physical examination shows brittle, coiled hair. There are scattered ecchymoses and petechiae over his lower extremities. His gums are swollen and bleed easily with gentle probing. There is mild tenderness in his knees and ankles, but no joint swelling or erythema. The rest of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 48-year-old man comes to the clinic because of bleeding gums, fatigue, and joint pain for the past three weeks. He is currently unemployed and has been living in a homeless shelter for the past two months. His diet consists mainly of bread and instant noodles; he rarely consumes fruits or vegetables. He has a history of alcohol use disorder and smokes one pack of cigarettes daily. The patient appears thin and pale. BMI is 17.3 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Physical examination shows brittle, coiled hair. There are scattered ecchymoses and petechiae over his lower extremities. His gums are swollen and bleed easily with gentle probing. There is mild tenderness in his knees and ankles, but no joint swelling or erythema. The rest of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This condition is caused by a nutritional deficiency, which leads to impaired collagen synthesis and fragile connective tissue.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical features of scurvy.

answers.explanation_why: Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is a congenital bleeding disorder characterized by mucocutaneous bleeding (e.g., bleeding gums, easy bruising) that typically manifests in childhood. vWD does not cause coiled hair or swollen gums.

Scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency. Classic features include fatigue, swollen and bleeding gums, poor wound healing, arthralgia, and characteristic skin findings (e.g., perifollicular hemorrhages, petechiae, ecchymoses, coiled hair). Risk factors include insufficient dietary intake of fruits and vegetables and alcohol use disorder. Scurvy should be considered in individuals with risk factors for poor nutritional intake (e.g., homelessness) who present with typical clinical features. Measurement of plasma or leukocyte vitamin C levels establishes the diagnosis. Treatment for scurvy is vitamin C supplementation.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) can manifest with fatigue, petechiae, ecchymoses, and mucosal bleeding. However, AML does not cause coiled hair or arthralgia and most commonly occurs in older individuals. Moreover, additional findings such as recurrent infections, fever, and hepatosplenomegaly would be expected in a patient with AML.

Liver cirrhosis can manifest with coagulopathy, easy bruising, and mucosal bleeding and can be caused by chronic alcohol use disorder. However, liver cirrhosis does not cause coiled hair, swollen gums, or arthralgia. Furthermore, additional dermal (e.g., pruritus, jaundice, palmar erythema, telangiectasia) and abdominal (e.g., hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, ascites) features, as well as features such as asterixis and Dupuytren contracture, would be expected in a patient with cirrhosis.

Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) typically manifests with petechiae, ecchymoses, and mucosal bleeding due to low platelet count as a result of immune destruction. However, ITP is not associated with swollen gums, coiled hair, or arthralgia.

question_text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of progressive weakness and numbness in his lower extremities. He also reports difficulty walking and occasional blurred vision. His medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus. He used to work as an accountant but lost his job 8 months ago. His diet has primarily consisted of white rice for the past 6 months due to socioeconomic hardship. His only medication is metformin, which he has been taking inconsistently for the past 8 months. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He appears thin and malnourished. His vital signs are within normal limits. Neurological examination shows bilateral foot drop, diminished sensation to light touch and pinprick in his hands and feet, and absent deep tendon reflexes in the lower extremities. Cranial nerve examination shows horizontal nystagmus. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of progressive weakness and numbness in his lower extremities. He also reports difficulty walking and occasional blurred vision. His medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus. He used to work as an accountant but lost his job 8 months ago. His diet has primarily consisted of white rice for the past 6 months due to socioeconomic hardship. His only medication is metformin, which he has been taking inconsistently for the past 8 months. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He appears thin and malnourished. His vital signs are within normal limits. Neurological examination shows bilateral foot drop, diminished sensation to light touch and pinprick in his hands and feet, and absent deep tendon reflexes in the lower extremities. Cranial nerve examination shows horizontal nystagmus. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's neurological examination shows findings of both peripheral and central nervous system involvement.
learning_objective: Recognize thiamine deficiency in patients with restricted diets.

answers.explanation_why: Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) can manifest with progressive, symmetrical, ascending weakness and areflexia but typically follows a recent infection and does not manifest with nystagmus. Therefore, an alternative diagnosis is more likely.

This patient's progressive symmetrical peripheral neuropathy (sensory and motor) and horizontal nystagmus, combined with his dietary history, strongly suggest thiamine deficiency. Chronic thiamine deficiency results in dry beriberi (characterized by symmetrical peripheral neuropathy and progressive muscle wasting) and Wernicke encephalopathy (characterized by confusion, oculomotor dysfunction with nystagmus, and gait ataxia). Some patients may also develop features of wet beriberi (e.g., high-output cardiac failure). Risk factors for thiamine deficiency include malnutrition, malabsorption, and heavy drinking. Thiamine replacement is essential to prevent irreversible neurological damage.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) can manifest with progressive weakness in the lower extremities. However, this patient presents with sensory loss, areflexia, and nystagmus, which are not features of ALS.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) can manifest with neurological deficits and nystagmus, but typically affects young adults. Additionally, episodes of neurological deficits in MS are separated in time and space, but this patient has chronic, progressive, symmetrical, ascending peripheral neuropathy with areflexia, making an alternative diagnosis more likely.

Diabetic neuropathy can manifest with symmetrical, distal sensorimotor polyneuropathy, but nystagmus is not a typical feature of this condition. This patient's dietary history and malnutrition make an alternative diagnosis more likely.
